content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of fibro-adipose tissue. Within this tissue, there are at least two well-circumscribed, ovoid, basophilic (dark purple) structures, which are characteristic of lymph nodes. One is located in the upper left quadrant and another in the lower right. The overall impression is a lymph node dissection specimen requiring evaluation for metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, the task is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of cancer spread. The green box is placed over the first identifiable lymph node from the top-left of the slide. Zooming into this area is a standard step to evaluate its architecture and cellular components at high magnification to rule out or confirm the presence of metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary goal in a colorectal cancer resection is to stage the tumor, which includes assessing the lymph nodes for metastasis (N stage). The green box is placed directly on one of the most prominent lymph nodes visible at low power (the one on the left). It is standard practice to systematically examine every lymph node at high magnification to screen for metastatic tumor cells, which can be present as small clusters in the subcapsular sinus or as larger deposits that efface the normal nodal architecture. This is a critical step in the diagnostic process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task for this type of specimen is to identify any lymph nodes containing metastatic tumor cells. The area indicated by the green box clearly contains one of the lymph nodes present on the slide. I would zoom into this area to begin the systematic high-power examination of each lymph node to assess its architecture and cellular composition, specifically searching for clusters of atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastasis from a primary colorectal adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the area at the interface between the second lymph node (the one on the lower right) and the adjacent perinodal adipose tissue. This is a critical location to examine for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the spread of metastatic tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the surrounding fat. The presence of ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor and needs to be carefully assessed and reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it contains one of the two distinct lymph nodes visible at low power (the one in the lower-right). It is standard practice to examine every identified lymph node at high magnification to screen for metastatic tumor cells. This particular node appears densely cellular, raising suspicion for either significant reactive changes or metastasis, making it a high-priority area to investigate. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node on the slide. The zoom area is focused on the second of the two visible lymph nodes, specifically at its periphery. This is a critical region to examine because the subcapsular sinus is the initial site where metastatic cells often deposit. Furthermore, assessing the interface between the lymph node capsule and the surrounding fat is essential to determine if there is extranodal extension (ENE), which is a key prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a portion of a lymph node adjacent to mature adipose tissue. The lymph node architecture appears preserved, with recognizable lymphoid follicles composed of dense collections of lymphocytes. I can see a mix of small and large lymphocytes and some sinus histiocytosis, which are features of a reactive process. There are no definitive signs of metastasis, such as atypical glands, clusters of malignant epithelial cells, or extensive necrosis. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a high-power image of the lymph node parenchyma. The field is densely populated with small, round, dark-staining cells, which are mature lymphocytes. There are some paler areas (sinuses) containing slightly larger cells with more cytoplasm, likely sinus histiocytes, indicating a reactive process. At the bottom left, there is a small aggregate of cells with more eosinophilic cytoplasm, possibly a small regressed germinal center. Critically, in this specific field of view, I do not see any definite evidence of metastasis. There are no atypical glandular formations, no nests of malignant epithelial cells, and no signet ring cells that would be characteristic of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific area is that of a benign, reactive lymph node. However, a definitive conclusion requires careful examination of the entire lymph node.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense, cellular lymphoid tissue. The cells are predominantly lymphocytes of varying sizes, consistent with a reactive lymph node follicle. There are small, dark lymphocytes (mantle zone) and larger lymphocytes with more open chromatin and visible nucleoli (germinal center cells). I do not see any definite nests, glands, or single-file infiltrates of atypical, large epithelial cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei, which would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastatic carcinoma. A complete evaluation would require examining the entire lymph node, including the subcapsular sinus.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, on the far right, there is a dense aggregate of basophilic cells, which represents part of the lymph node, likely infiltrated by metastatic carcinoma. To the left of this, infiltrating the adipose tissue, there is a prominent desmoplastic stromal reaction, characterized by pink, fibrillar collagen. Within this desmoplastic stroma and between the fat cells, there are scattered atypical cells with dark, irregular nuclei, present singly and in small clusters. These findings are diagnostic of extranodal extension of metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a portion of the lymph node. I can clearly see sheets and nests of non-native, malignant epithelial cells replacing the normal lymphoid tissue. These cells are large, have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, and pleomorphic, hyperchromatic to vesicular nuclei. They are forming poorly differentiated glandular structures. This is a classic presentation of metastatic adenocarcinoma within a lymph node, confirming that this is a positive (metastatic) lymph node.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I can see the edge of the lymph node, characterized by a dense infiltrate of small, dark lymphocytes. Adjacent to this lymphoid tissue, in the surrounding adipose and fibrous tissue, there are irregular clusters and single atypical cells. These cells are larger than the lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The presence of these tumor cells outside the main contour of the lymph node, infiltrating the pericapsular fat, is definitive evidence of extranodal extension (ENE). My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with ENE.
